tip: Seek shade mid day. Sun is most intense between between the hours of 10 A.M. and 4 P.M.
Often we don’t apply enough sunscreen. Try reapplying 20 minutes later after the first application to compensate for the initial under-application.
Reapply sunscreen after a vigorous activity. Sunscreen is removed by swimming and excessive sweating.
When the UV Index is 9, you can get a sunburn in less than 20 minutes.
Even when the UV Index is 4, a sunburn is possible within 50 minutes.
Up to 80 percent of UV rays pass through clouds. A sunburn is possible on cloudy days.
Snow, water, and sand increase sun exposure by reflecting incoming UV rays. It's important for skiers, boaters, and beachcombers to reapply sunscreen often.
Wear sunscreens that offer protection from both UVA and UVB rays.
According to FDA, “water resistant” sunscreens must maintain their SPF after 40 minutes of water immersion, while “very water resistant” must maintain their SPF after 80 minutes of water immersion.
The Shadow rule - look at your shadow and if it is shorter than your height this means that the sun’s UV rays are strong.
The Shadow rule - look at your shadow and if it is shorter than your height this means that the sun’s UV rays are strong.
All skin tones need sunscreen even if you rarely get burned.
UV rays still penetrate the glass in your office and your car.
For a day outdoors, we recommend SPF 50 and don’t forget to reapply every two hours.
